zines.description: <div>Maximumrocknroll, often written as Maximum Rocknroll and usually abbreviated as MRR, is a not-for-profit monthly zine of punk subculture. Based in San Francisco, MRR focuses on punk rock and hardcore music, and primarily features artist interviews and music reviews. Op/ed columns and news roundups are regular features as well, including submissions from international contributors. By 1990, it "had become the de facto bible of the scene". The very first time readers got their hands ink-stained with the pages of Maximum Rocknroll, it was through the zine insert for the now-classic Cali punk/HC compilation Not So Quiet on the Western Front. Right from the beginning, MRR wanted to have its hands in everything DIY punk: zines, records, radio, show spaces, politics, and more. That locals-only double LP was released by then-MRR Radio collaborator Jello

For the past two decades, young women (and men) have found their way to feminism through Riot Grrrl. Against the backdrop of the culture wars and before the rise of the Internet or desktop publishing, the zine and music culture of the Riot Grrrl movement empowered young women across the country to speak out against sexism and oppression, creating a powerful new force of liberation and unity within and outside of the women's movement. The Punk Singer is a 2013 documentary film about feminist singer Kathleen Hanna who fronted the bands Bikini Kill and Le Tigre, and who was a central figure in the riot grrrl movement. Directed by filmmaker Sini Anderson and produced by Anderson and Tamra Davis, the film's title is taken from the Julie Ruin song "The Punk Singer", from Hanna's 1998 solo effort.  (taken from Wikipedia)

Directed by: Sini Anderson
Producers: Sini Anderson, Gwen Bialic, Tamra Davis, Rachel Dengiz, Er

Inklings & Musings is a zine made in Los Angeles, California. This is the first issue made in Winter of 1993. This issue includes interviews with Jeremy Eaton and Ernest Mann. Includes reviews of LPs from The Jon Spencer Blues Explosion, Bikini Kill, The Plasmatics, Velocity Girl, Nirvana, and many more. Also has reviews of live shows from bands like Smashing Pumpkings, Mudhoney, Nirvana, Tiny Tim, and more.

Sloan’s Tour Book #1 zine, from 1993, which features record reviews (Jellyfish Babies, Merge, Eric’s Trip, Chaz Rules, Bikini Kill, etc.), articles such as Patrick Pentland’s then-recent excursion to the UK (1993) and his “Real Guide to England”, “Canada: The Music Ghetto” by Chris Murphy and more.

zines.zine_name: Gayotic with MUNA - Shout Out To ___ with Kathleen Hanna (Video Episode)
zines.description:
This week, the band is joined by singer, musician, pioneer of the feminist punk riot grrrl movement, punk zine writer, and most recently memoir author Kathleen Hanna! Together, the group confide their tricks to get through the early days of touring, the differences between coming up as a band between the 90s and now, and the thrill of a beautiful miniature display.

Kathleen's book, Rebel Girl: My Life as a Feminist Punk, is out now! Buy it here:

Tile: Girl Cola

zines.zine_name: Stories of American Punk and Alternative Music
zines.description: This collection delves into unique and vibrant music scenes, including those in Southern California and Olympia, Washington. It examines how these regions gave birth to diverse musical movements, from punk and hardcore to ska and alternative rock. These works explore the cultural, social, and political dimensions of the music, shedding light on the significance of these sounds in shaping the identity of suburban areas. From the overlooked bands of Long Beach to the emergence of grunge and riot g

A zine discussing the history of queercore zines through a trans/gender variant lens. Created by Ashton Thorne, graveyardpansy, as a part of their 2022 research project focusing on the history of trans representation in queercore zines.

zines.description:
Queercore: How to Punk a Revolution: An Oral History is the very first compre-hensive overview of a movement that defied both the music underground and the LGBT mainstream community.

This is issue #20 of Smash It Up, which is a Toronto punk fanzine put out by Nick Smash. This issue came out in December 1981. The issue starts out with a road trip diary for the Young Lions and 20th Century Rebels for a nuclear disarmament benefit show they play in Montreal. It didn't go so well. 

There is an article on the Professionals who played the Voodoo Club. there is bits of an interview with Paul Cook in the piece. 

There is an interview with Simple Minds who are from Scotland. This w

This issue came out in April 2008. The issue starts out with an interview of Hard Charger from Fredricton. An old interview with Boulevard Trash got published. A travel diary of Craig and Leah of their latest trip in Japan. Reviews of "Punk is Dead: Punk is Everything" and "Manchild" were in this issue. There were also reviews, gossip, show listings, and a flyers page.

There is this old Cometbus zine that seems fitting.  In it is a short essay that must be his most loved piece of writing.  Ive seen it photocopied and taped up on bedroom walls quite often.  "Punk Rock Love Is" is its title.  Cometbus lists the so called "pure moments" he will always remember from a whirlwind romance he had with an older punk while in high school.  My favorite line, which I think sums it all up is "Punk rock love is a collection of those pure moments you remember no matter what

Slug and Lettuce is a free newsprint punk zine started in State College, Pennsylvania by Chris Boarts in 1987. In 1989 CBL and S&L relocated to New York City where the zine's print run steadily grew and increased to 10,000 with free worldwide distribution. In 1997, CBL and S&L relocated to Richmond, Virginia. Its byline reads "A zine supporting the Do-It-Yourself ethics of the punk community". The print version ended in 2007 with edition #90, and the PO Box was closed in 2016.

Punk Planet was a 16,000 print run punk zine, based in Chicago, Illinois, that focused most of its energy on looking at punk subculture rather than punk as simply another genre of music to which teenagers listen. In addition to covering music, Punk Planet also covered visual arts and a wide variety of progressive issues — including media criticism, feminism, and labor issues.

zines.description: This is a four-panel pamphlet (it prints best on legal size paper) that provides a short guide to preventing sexual assault. It's targeted primarily at the punk and/or anarchist subculture, but provides important information regardless of subcultural affiliation. Topics covered include defining sexual assault, alcohol and sexual assault, how to watch out for yourself and your friends, what to do if you or a friend are sexually assaulted, and how to help a survivor. zines.description:
Subvert 4 (1982)

Here you go, an 'early 80's classic from Keighley' - so says Sned over at the UK Zine Library where the lad has uploaded issues 2, 3 and 5 - collected here at Punks is Hippies. I agree, it's a belter, especially appealing for those with an anarcho/industrial bent - - spot-on work by Richard Jevons. This is a tri-fold pamphlet that explains the basic concepts of consent. It includes how we define "no," a series of questions to ask yourself and about consent and your understanding of it, and suggested ways of asking for consent. It's an excellent pamphlet to distribute when tabling, at anarchist spaces, at punk shows, or wherever it might be needed. "Let's Talk Consent" is a good introduction to the topic and includes suggestions for further reading.

In this zine, the Philly Dudes Collectiveâan anti-sexist "men's group" that came out of the radical/anarchist and punk scenes in Philadelphiaâgives an overview of their work during the first year of their existence. It includes a sampling of posters they used to promote their events, workshops and discussions they led, panels they participated on, etc. They offer good outlines for hosting conversations on masculinity and patriarchy and men's roles in it. This is an excellent resource for anyone

Black Eye was a zine out of New York, and this book offers some of the best pieces from this fiesty, piss-and-vinegar, punk-inspired series. Pieces on living your life creatively at work, fiction starring John Zerzan, journal notes on the process of a budding anarchist leaving a Trotskyist group, the taking (and taking back) of Tompkin Square Park, the significance of play, and much more.

Black Eye was born pathogenic and perverse in a basement in the Lower East Side's Heart of Darkne

Shades Magazine was a publication from Toronto that covered punk back in the early days. they were a tabloid size and as a result were taken seriously as they were printed on a printing press. This is issue 25 which came out in September 1982. The issue contained interviews with Billy Idol, Stray Cats, Haircut 100, Duran Duran, Jim Carroll, Los Microwaves, and Nina Hagen. Locally this issue covered the Rent Boys Inc, Breeding ground, the Payolas, and the Ugly Ducklings.

Rapid Eye Movement wasis a brilliant fanzine. Sadly departed R.E.M. ed. Simon Dwyer's inspired delving yielded-up a celebrated corpus sublime. Mining a rare seam, Simon hewed from a fissure where music, politics, culture and the occult converged ('Occulture'); always deftly swerving the decent into accursed obscurantism. He'd go on to do a stint at Sounds and eventually launch 'Occulture' in earnest with the 1989 publication of Rapid Ey

zines.description:
Peroxide 1 (1979)

Oh yes, it's another cracker. Quentin 'Norman' Cook's, Andrew Thomas' and Ian Laidlaw's Peroxide ticks all the boxes offering practical advice, good writing, neat layout, great use of graphics, cool photos and multiple entreaties for punters to get involved. The 2nd and last issue acknowledges the encouragement and input from fellow fanzine writers so I'll be sure to post that at some point. Really, the only downside with this smasher is that onl

This issue of Smash It Up is all about politics. This issue came out in November 1980.

It starts out with an article on the KKK trying to start up a chapter in Toronto and the writer calls for a media blackout of the organization. 

THis is followed by a piece on Rock Against Racism which looked at how the organization evolved in Toronto. They mentioned the Englisn roots to the organization with bands like Elvis Costello and Gang of Four and the Specials and the Clash. And then there was refere
Forget It! fanzine No 7.  1982.  California Punk Rock.

London's Burning 1 (1976)

A big treat here for Clash fans - Jonh Ingham's stylish London's Burning. It's a very nifty piece indeed with some fantastic collage work. Apart from this wonderful fanzine Ingham is credited with conducting the first Sex Pistols interview (published in Sounds, 24 April '76), writing the Rough Trade Newsletter, and penning many freelance pieces about the emergent Punk scene for papers such as Sounds and NME. Jonh writes on- you can read h
El Sótano en distintos espacios de la ciudad y otros parches/lugares en otras ciudades en Colombia y del mundo, donde ha llegado el material que narra las memorias Subterráneas del Punk Medallo.

Red Tank!'s second zine

Un año convulso en medio de la pandemia. Sin embargo, esto no fue problema para seguir escudriñando las memorias subterráneas y publicar como nos gusta.

Estas ediciones son fanzines que se concentraron como siempre en los Archivos, Lugares y Repertorios de la memoria en el Punk en Medellín, esta vez pensando en la década 1995-2005. Como siempre, tuvimos la dicha de conspirar con nuestro hermano de la vida Alex Kuervo y su armadillo Sangrante.

zines.zine_name: Spitboy Rule: Tales of a Xicana in a Female Punk Band
zines.description:
Michelle Cruz Gonzales played drums and wrote lyrics in the influential 1990s female hardcore band Spitboy, and now she’s written a book—a punk rock herstory. Though not a riot grrl band, Spitboy blazed trails for women musicians in the San Francisco Bay Area and beyond, but it wasn’t easy. Misogyny, sexism, abusive fans, class and color blindness, and all-out racism were foes, especially for Gonzales, a Xicana and the only person of color in the band.
Unlike touring rock bands before them, the

zines.description: <div>40 years after kick-starting the global punk movement, London holds what may be the largest punk scene in existence. Splintered into a number of sub-scenes based around different genres and places but unified by an anti-authoritarian attitude, the scene rejects dominant values and normalizes a range of radical convictions, including ethical veganism. Despite aptness for sociological study, both ‘punk veganism’ and the London punk scene have received little academic attention and this study

zines.description: This is everything I know or could find out about doing a small Do It Yourself punk independent show. It is way too much Information, but I wanted to make sure that few questions went unanswered.

1-page zine that I made and distributed by hand in 1992/93 while living in the Washington, D.C. and Richmond, Virginia metropolitan areas.

While my band Askance was touring the East Coast in 1993, I brought several hundred copies along and passed them out before and after shows.

All in all, the total number of printed copies was under 1,000 (at the least there were probably 500 total).

zines.zine_name: Hunger Is A Shape I Wear
zines.description: Hunger Is A Shape I Wear is a raw, visceral zine by Shimi & Critter exploring the intersections of anorexia, dysphoria, therianthropy, and survival. This isn’t a recovery manual—it’s a survival log. A brutally honest account of what it means to be a trans Therian navigating a world that misgenders, misunderstands, and malnourishes.

zines.zine_name: what about the rapists? anarchist approaches to crime & justice
zines.description:
This zine looks at contemporary anarchist theory and practice on crime and justice, though it won't be using these terms. The first half will be a critical examination of Transformative Justice-based accountability processes, an approach with origins in US anarchist circles now taking seed in parts of Europe. The other half looks at retributive approaches, such as survivor-led direct action against rapists.

zines.zine_name: Beyond Society How Therians Build Their Own Systems Of Care Through Pack, Warren, Pride, And Flock Life Booklet
zines.description:
"Beyond Society: How Therians Build Their Own Systems of Care Through Pack, Warren, Pride, and Flock Life"

This zine, part of the HOWL series, offers a deep exploration into how Therians—those who experience themselves as non-human creatures—form systems of care that transcend societal expectations. It delves into how these kinship structures, rooted in the instincts of animals, provide support and survival outside the confines of bureaucracy and state systems.

The 38th issue of the Ukrainian DIY punk zine FontarЪ explores how punk aesthetics and resistance evolve beyond music — through art, performance, noise, protest, and memory. This issue features articles on punk in galleries, noise as installation, the body as protest (Marina Abramović, Pussy Riot, FEMEN), and the visual legacy of subcultures. Includes a detailed history of the Misfits, the straight edge movement, the emo scene, and sketchbooks as cultural resistance.

zines.zine_name: Sum 41 & The Offspring 2023 Vegan Zine ( Less Black Ink)
zines.description:
The title of the zine is, "What Do Guitarist Tom Thacker of Sum 41 and Bassist Todd Morse of The Offspring Have in Common? (Besides Shredding)" and was created by vegan activist Colburn Clark in August of 2023.

It's 8 pages, has quotes from Todd Morse and Tom Thacker of the bands Sum 41 and The Offspring, who are both vegan, in favor of animal rights and veganism. There is a QR code that links to the documentary Dominion on YouTube.

zines.zine_name: The FLUKE Mini-Comics & Zine Festival Archive: Stewarding 20+ Years of Jamming Econo, Community Collaboration, And Creative Print Culture in Athens, Georgia
zines.description: This white paper, written by two of FLUKE's co-founders, chronicles the FLUKE Mini-Comics & Zine Festival in Athens, Georgia, highlighting its significance as a grassroots platform for independent artists. It discusses FLUKE's history, community impact, and collaboration with Hargrett Library at the University of Georgia Libraries to create an archive. The text explores the challenges and opportunities of preserving zines and other DIY creative works, emphasizing the importance of community

The second issue of Personality Liberation Front, a feminist punk zine produced in Brisbane in 1999 by official hooligans Kylie & Kath, dedicated to challenging mainstream society's ideals and gender stereotypes as well as to putting the so-called "liberated" diy-hardcorepunk scene under the microscope.

Di edisi ke 4 ini urjensi mencoba menulis dengan sudut pandang saya sendiri tentang apa yang saya baca dan yang saya lihat dan juga ada beberapa sumbangan tulisan dari kawan-kawanku.

Bukan ingin menjadi sok intelek atau sok paling mengerti segalanya, meskipun saya juga masih belajar menulis dan masih kurang membaca. Di zine ini saya tidak muluk-muluk, saya hanya ingin menulis sesuai dengan apa yang saya ketahui. Masih sama seperti zine edisi sebelumnya dimana tulisan saya

This is a PDF of the January 2015 issue of EXD fanzine. This issue features an interview with the School Jerks. The School Jerks are a hardcore band from Toronto with a strong early Black Flag influence in sound and art. The band has released a demo, three eps, a split tape, an LP and appeared on a few comps. This interview attempts to look back at the band with a focus on the LP as that is the band's most recent release. I find the band very inspiring.

zines.zine_name: Sunflo'er: A Fanzine for All These Darlings and now Me!
zines.description:
An analogue/digital lyric fanzine for New York experimental hardcore band Sunflo'er's album "all these darlings and now me".
  This beautifully crafted mixed media zine was made with amazing attention to detail, and is a personal love letter of sorts to the band by the author, who came to befriend the members of Sunflo'er during her time living in Potsdam New York.

This is the third issue of the seminal zine "Girl Germs" by  Allison Wolfe and Molly Neuman (Bratmobile). This issue has a personal piece written by "Lainga" about being the child of Chinese immigrants in America. There is also a piece by Dana Younkins (Cuntz with Attitude), and a lot of other great early riot grrrl pieces.

This issue is a copy of a copy of a copy, so photo details are lost and some text can be difficult to read.

Profane Existence #26

Spring 1994

This history makes use of anti-social theory to take a broad and
multifaceted look at queer-feminist punk—from its origins in the
1980s to its contemporary influences on the Occupy movement
and Pussy Riot activism.

 - Pass Becoming a Hive of Big Industries with Blairmore as the Great Distributing Centre 
 
 - Town Council Favor Extension of Victoria St

 - Ladies Play Fast Game Hockey-May Issue Broad Challenge

zines.zine_name: This Rancid Mill: An Alex Damage Novel
zines.description:
With his blue mohawk and ragged leather jacket, Alex Damage fits in to only a small pocket of 1981 Los Angeles: the dynamic, changing punk scene.
In this world, he survives on favors and reputation as a small-time private investigator, but when a young woman hires him to solve the potential murder of the singer of one of his favorite local bands, everything in his life amps up. As he digs deeper into what really happened, Alex must both seek out and dodge an endless array of dangerously powerful

V Sign 3 (1980)

There's a pointer back to the last post in this V Sign - editor Les comments on a particular short piece: ‘this bit hasn’t worked, KYPP#2 has some of my feelings put into words but I can’t do that very well – it all sounds too obvious’. Peer referencing was something of a theme and it's one of the charms of these fanzines; the dialogue among them - the encouragement and camaraderie, the barbs, feuds and spats. En invierno de 1993 aparecía en el mercado el primer número de Mondo Brutto, un fanzine que iba a marcar un antes y un después en la historia subterránea de las publicacione

Fanzine punk de poesía contra-cultural

Una nueva edición cargada de narrativas subterráneas que ubican algunos elementos críticos sobre las formas de hacer memoria y las experiencias que son importantes revisar en la historia de algunos parches de Punk en la ciudad en donde las contradicciones se han manifestado.

Diagramado por Alex Cuervo y con la gráfica de Salve.

Fanzines publicados durante el 2023 de forma autónoma y con la complicidad de nuestrxs amigxs de siempre. 

Ediciones conmemorativas por los 5 años del proyecto fanzine que resaltan los aportes de nuestras amigas, y dan cabida a ese ir y venir de las memorias presentes en la movida Punk de Medellín.

Todas estas ediciones fueron creadas en nuestra guarida, desde nuestra casa como lugar para la resistencia.

Recopilación de comic subterráneo del Pun Medallo desde la década de los 90. Surgido en el municipio aledaño de Bello, RATAX es una de las primeras historietas inspiradas en el Punk del Valle de Aburrá.

La presente recopilación no es un ejercicio acabado, pues el archivo es mucho más grande y aún está construyéndose. Sin embargo, para El Sótano, este es un sentido homenaje a una parte del trabajo de mi amigo y hermano Alex Cuervo..
Fanzine realizado por █████ .

Fanzine punk de poesía contra-cultural

En creuar en solitud el llindar d’El Punt, t’envolta un silenci quasi sepulcral. Els documents, organitzats (a vegades) en caixes, s’amunteguen verticalment grisos de pols, com tombes als nínxols. La immensitat dels materials aclapara: Fanzines, adhesius i xapes. Calaveres, cartells i quadres de Durruti. Un telèfon retro dels anys setanta i un senyor fumant a la porta. Tot adquireix certa aura de tanatori o de necròpolis

Toxic Graffiti 4 (1979) Toxic Grafitty

For sure, TG#4 is jam-packed - practically every inch of page space is utilised. Excellent articles/interviews featuring a seminal bunch of artists: The Eratics, Heretics, Rubella Ballet, Epileptics, Materialschlact, and Mick Duffield offers an extensive breakdown of his film Autopsy. Penny Rimbaud writes, 'Following the 8/9/79 Conway Hall Agro', and elsewhere Mike offers comments on that ill-fated gig. Lots more Mike musings

Hardkode Zine 00

Un fanzine hecho en la Ciudad de México, en donde el punk y la cultura hacker se encuentran.

Recopilado de las presentaciones y eventos que se tuvieron durante el 2020 en distintos lugares y espacios donde participó la investigación El Sótano.

Felices de continuar con amigxs construyendo y posibilitando debates alrededor de las Memorias Subterráneas del Punk en Medellín.

Ребро Жёсткости 2 (2000)

Ребро Жесткости. Ещё один раритетный позитивный панк straight edge фэнзин из Минска, Беларусь от Димы и Жени. В первом номере ни одного интервью, ни одной рецензии, только лишь статьи и идеи: стрейтэдж, история ска, история возникновения настоящих скинов. Come over , we can , and we will (2023) is a 60-part photo series of in/decent bodies originally printed in April 2023, curated by Tyko Say. The objective of the project was for the viewer to challenge their comforts and ideals towards bodies and sex.

The photos are as realistic as the datasets they originate from. Our comforts and ideals are, equally, as realistic as the datasets we originate from.

This zine explores the relationship between punk music and anarchism, tracing how punk emerged from 1960s countercultures and played a central role in the resurgence of anarchism globally in the late 20th century. It discusses how punk prefigured participatory media of the digital age and what its legacy can teach us today. It examines how punk combined DIY ethos, raw aesthetics, and a global network of resistance. Finally, it looks at the role punk plays today.

This zine was born out of the anger, fear and hate for the outcome of the 2024 election and the events that have taken place afterwards. Here you will find my initial reaction, which is a piece called “Dear America”, the main reasons why I believe this clown being president is extremely concerning, a music recommendation and a couple of fun lists. 
I believe that minorities constitute a great revolutionary force, and we will survive these 4 years that keep getting more authoritari

zines.zine_name: Burn Collector: Collected Stories from One through Nine
zines.description: Burn Collector compiles the first nine issues of Al Burian’s sporadically published and widely acclaimed personal zine. Beginning in the mid-nineties, Burian distributed his work through the tight-knit network of the DIY punk music scene. Burn Collector caught on because of its unusual content—in a scene rife with dogmatic political diatribes and bland record reviews, Burian presented his readers with humorous anecdotes, philosophical musings, and nuanced descriptions of odd locales and curious

<div style="color:rgb(44,44,44);font-family:'Helvetica Neue', Helvetica, Arial, sans-serif;font-size:14px;background-color:rgb(255,255,255);">Az első, teljes egészében az ipari és EBM-kultúrának dedikált magyar nyelvű fanzin, amelynek szerkesztői nemcsak fanzint készítettek, hanem eseményeket is szerveztek. Az 1991 és 1993 között öt számot megért kiadvány következetesen (és mai szemszögből meglepően) "techno fanzinnak" aposztrofálja magát, tartalma alapján viszont egyértelműen ipari. Kinyúlt azo

Fanzine Anarkopunk

Contenidos:

- Editorial
- Crítica destructiva
- Poema "Nihil"
- El cantante de MG-15 es candidato de Vox y los punks enfermos de estupidez

Stáb: Kővári Péter, Pauer Péter, Bodrossy Márk (tördelés, szerkesztés)

A Vírus mellett a győri Phobia a másik magyar nyelvű fanzin, ami teljes egészében az (elektro)industrial szubkultúrának dedikált, nyilvánvaló kitekintésekkel a technokultúra felé. A fanzin mögött álló stáb volt felelős az industrial.hu és az ahhoz kötődő ipari levelezőlista működéséért, amey a social media oldalak megjelenése előtt biztos közösségi pontot és információosztó bázist jelentet

Stáb: Kővári Péter, Pauer Péter, Bodrossy Márk (tördelés, szerkesztés)

A Vírus mellett a győri Phobia a másik magyar nyelvű fanzin, ami teljes egészében az (elektro)industrial szubkultúrának dedikált, nyilvánvaló kitekintésekkel a technokultúra felé. A fanzin mögött álló stáb volt felelős az industrial.hu és az ahhoz kötődő ipari levelezőlista működéséért, amey a social media oldalak megjelenése előtt biztos közösségi pontot és információosztó

"A Magnát azzal a szándékkal indítottuk útnak, hogy intellektuális inspirációt, lelki élményeket nyújtson. A zene a folyóirat készítőinek szenvedélye, összeköt minket, ezért választottuk alapul és központi témául. (...) A magyar underground zenék támogatása kiemelt célunk, hiszen fontosnak tartjuk, hogy a hozzánk legközelebb eső értékeket bemutassuk."

Így nyilatkoznak a szerkesztők a Magna #4 előszavában. A Last Exit lemezboltot is üzemeltető szerkesztők bő ereszt

Lo vi fijamente a los ojos, buscado en ellos, la bola de crystal que le robo a una gitana. ¿Qué buscas jefe? zines.zine_name: La Cabra La Puta De La Cabra
zines.description: El que me digan señor ya es de lo más habitual, sin duda ya no hay forma en que pueda ocultar o disfrazar mi edad, y no es que lo allá hecho, bueno no del todo. Todos envejecemos eso lo tengo claro, también, tengo claro que el envejecer no es sinónimo de valer verga, o quien sabe la verdad, el chiste es hasta que punto es decir no pues ya estoy viejo, y a mi me está pasando al escribir esto.

Az 1989 és 1990 között kilenc számot megért Alterock ritka hollója a hazai underground kiadványoknak: jó designnal, jó szerzőcsapattal, értő módon, jó témákról író kiadvány volt. Az A/3 méretű, 16 oldalon megjelenő magazin (ami infrastruktúráját és szervezettségét tekintve már inkább volt a rendszerváltás utáni zenei magazin, mint fanzin) bátor kézzel nyúlt két kézzel az underground(abb) zenék mélyére: a Survival Research Labstől Laurie Andersonig, az ACTUS-tól az Auróráig.

Los cuadros se hicieron famosos por su inscripción (en francés), Ceci n'est pas une pipe, la cual en castellano significa: «Esto no es una pipa»-la intención de -esta foto-era comentar-sobre lo que pase con-lo concheros-en un viaje- mal pedo que pase- pero -para mi resulta-inevitable-ver el -error como algo-gracioso-y no se-esto no es un pene-

Pero quién sabe si es una ansia de pez con la boca abierta que tiene el ahogado antes de morir, y entonces se dice que antes de sumergirse para siempre un hombre ve pasar ante sus ojos su vida entera si un instan tente se nace un instante se muere, un instante es bastante para vida entera. La manzana en la oscuridad.

It was published by the SFCA, which also published other fanzines such as the ROCKET’S BLAST COMICCOLLECTOR. In this issue White Indian by Frazetta is reprinted, followed by The Lost Lives of Laura Hastings with art by Al Williamson and Captain Science and the Insidious Doctor Khartoum

zines.description: <div>A rarely documented, highly important doujin series from the circle P.L.O, or Perfective Latent Organization. This group is hardly documented as the group, which was invite only and quite strict, did not sell their works at Comiket. The group was originally headed by a Daisuke Hanaro (大介 花郎), a pseudonym for one of the female members, alongside the novelist Mirai Okuda (奥田未来) and mangaka Jun Goto (後藤順). A wise man once said to me, "zines are bullshit.  Kids who do zines only do it to get free stuff.  They put garbage in it and only go up to issue 2".  That very same man got hit by a truck the other day.  Oh well.  The point he was trying to make though was that most zines are bullshit.  And they are to a point I guess.  But in another way, every zine is a work of art.  Priceless to some, but shit to others. I am really proud of this issue

What inspired me to do this zine the most would have to be Las Vegas.  The scene here sucks.  It's so unorganized that the average scenester like myself can't bear to just sit back and watch.  So I did this because I think the thing that lacks most in Vegas is zines.  I seriously haven't seen a decent local zine around for almost a year, and that's just ridiculous!  So, for the past ten months or so I've been writing.
